definitions: break open or apart suddenly and violently from internal pressure
suddenly experience and express a strong feeling or emotion uncontrollably
move or enter somewhere suddenly with great force and energy
examples: The water balloon burst when it hit the ground
The pipe burst during the freezing winter night
She burst into tears after hearing the news
The children burst out laughing at the funny joke
He burst through the door to escape the fire
The athletes burst from the starting blocks immediately

definitions: put a dead body in the ground or place something underground
hide or cover something completely so it cannot be seen or found
involve oneself deeply and completely in an activity or situation
examples: They buried their beloved dog in the backyard garden
The archaeologists discovered treasures buried centuries ago underground
She buried the evidence in the woods behind the house
The old secrets were buried in forgotten archives
He buried himself in his work after the divorce
She buried her face in the soft pillow

definitions: grow or spread out thickly like a bush or shrub
avoid giving a direct answer or dealing with something directly
examples: The plant bushed out after the spring pruning session
Her hair bushed around her face in the humidity
Stop bushing around and tell me what really happened
Politicians often bush when asked difficult policy questions

definitions: perform music or entertainment in public places for voluntary donations
examples: She busked on the subway platform every weekend morning
The musicians busked outside the theater before the show

definitions: break something or become broken with sudden violent force
arrest someone or raid a place as part of law enforcement
fail completely or go bankrupt in business or other ventures
examples: The kids busted the window playing baseball in the yard
The old chair finally busted under his weight
Police busted the drug dealers in a dawn raid operation
They busted him for speeding on the highway yesterday
The company busted after years of poor financial management
Their marriage busted after only six months together

definitions: move in an energetic and busy way through a crowded space
make a place full of activity and energetic movement
examples: She bustled through the market carrying her heavy shopping bags
Waiters bustled between tables during the dinner rush hour
The preparations bustled the entire household for days before
The festival bustled the quiet town with unexpected activity

definitions: keep someone occupied with work or activities to do
occupy oneself with a particular activity or task
examples: She busied the children with art projects all afternoon
The manager busied his team with urgent deadline tasks
He busied himself organizing papers while waiting nervously
They busied themselves preparing for the important guests

definitions: kill and prepare animals for meat in a professional manner
do something very badly through lack of skill or care
kill people or animals in a cruel and violent way
examples: The farmer butchered the cattle for the winter meat supply
He learned to butcher game during his hunting apprenticeship
The actor completely butchered his lines during the performance
She butchered the song with her terrible singing voice
The invading army butchered innocent civilians without mercy
The serial killer butchered his victims in horrific ways

definitions: strike or push against something with the head or horns
place two things together so their ends touch or meet
intrude or interfere in someone else's business or conversation
examples: The goat butted the fence trying to escape the pen
The ram butted heads with his rival during mating season
The carpenter carefully butted the boards together for seamless joining
Make sure the tiles butt perfectly against each other
Stop butting into our private conversation without being invited
He always butts in when we're trying to work

definitions: spread butter or a similar substance on bread or food
praise or flatter someone excessively to gain favor or advantage
examples: She buttered the toast while the coffee was brewing slowly
He carefully buttered the pan before adding the eggs
Stop buttering up the boss just to get that promotion
She buttered him with compliments before asking for money

definitions: swim using the butterfly stroke with both arms moving simultaneously
cut food almost in half and spread it flat for cooking
examples: She butterflied across the pool in record-breaking time yesterday
He learned to butterfly after mastering the other swimming strokes
The chef butterflied the chicken breast before grilling it
Butterfly the shrimp by cutting along the back carefully

definitions: fasten clothing or fabric using buttons through buttonholes
press or push a button to operate a device
examples: She buttoned her coat against the cold winter wind
He carefully buttoned his shirt before the important meeting
Button the elevator to go to the tenth floor
She buttoned the remote to change the television channel

definitions: obtain something by paying money in exchange for goods or services
believe or accept something as true or valid without question
obtain something valuable through sacrifice or at great personal cost
examples: She bought groceries for the week at the local supermarket
They bought their first house after years of saving
I don't buy his excuse for being late again
The jury didn't buy the defendant's alibi story
He bought time by asking complicated questions during negotiations
They bought peace with significant territorial concessions

definitions: make a continuous low humming or vibrating sound like a bee
move somewhere quickly and busily with energy and purpose
be filled with excitement or animated discussion and activity
call or contact someone using a telephone or intercom system
examples: Bees buzzed around the colorful flowers in the garden
The old refrigerator buzzed loudly throughout the night
She buzzed around the office preparing for the meeting
Cars buzzed past on the busy highway during rush hour
The whole school buzzed with rumors about the new teacher
The crowd buzzed with anticipation before the concert started
Buzz me when you arrive at the building entrance
I'll buzz you on the intercom to let you in

definitions: travel somewhere by taking a taxi or cab for transportation
work as a taxi driver transporting passengers for payment
examples: We cabbed it to the airport to save time
They cabbed home after the late night party ended
He cabbed for twenty years before retiring from driving
She cabs on weekends to earn extra money

definitions: engage in secret plotting or intrigue against someone or something
examples: The ministers caballed against the unpopular prime minister secretly
They caballed in dark corners planning their corporate takeover

definitions: confine or shut someone in a small space like a cabin
stay or live in a cabin especially for vacation or isolation
examples: They were cabined in the small room during the storm
The prisoners were cabined together in cramped quarters overnight
We cabin in the mountains every summer for two weeks
They cabined by the lake to escape city life

definitions: send a message or communication using telegraph cable or electronic means
secure or fasten something using strong cable or wire rope
provide or install cable television or internet service to a location
examples: She cabled the urgent news to headquarters immediately yesterday
They cabled money to their son studying abroad
The workers cabled the heavy equipment to the crane securely
We need to cable the boat to the dock properly
The company cabled our neighborhood last month for internet
They're cabling the entire building with fiber optic connections

definitions: hide or store something in a secret place for future use
store data temporarily in computer memory for faster access later
examples: The pirates cached their treasure on the deserted island
Squirrels cache nuts for the long winter months ahead
The browser caches frequently visited websites for faster loading
The system caches data to improve overall performance speed

definitions: work as a golf caddie carrying clubs and advising players
examples: He caddied for professional golfers during summer tournaments
She caddied at the country club to pay for college

definitions: serve as a golf caddie carrying equipment and giving advice
examples: He caddied every weekend at the exclusive golf resort
She learned to caddy from her father's golfing friends

definitions: put or keep an animal or person in a cage or prison
surround or enclose something with bars or protective framework
examples: They caged the wild birds illegally captured from forests
The zoo caged the dangerous animals for visitor safety
The construction workers caged the elevator shaft for safety
They caged the machinery to prevent workplace accidents

definitions: form or cause to form into a thick solid mass or crust
cover something with a thick layer of another substance
examples: The mud caked on his boots after the rainy hike
Blood caked around the wound overnight before treatment began
Snow caked the car windshield during the winter storm
Makeup caked her face after the long photo shoot

definitions: determine something by using mathematical methods or numerical computation
plan something carefully and deliberately with a specific intention
estimate or assess something carefully based on available information
examples: She calculated the total cost of materials for the project
The computer calculates millions of operations per second automatically
He calculated every move to win the chess championship
They calculated their response to maximize political advantage
Scientists calculated the age of the fossil using carbon dating
We calculated our chances of success before proceeding

definitions: enter or schedule an event on a calendar for planning purposes
arrange or organize events chronologically by date and time
examples: She calendared all the meetings for next month carefully
Make sure to calendar the deadline to avoid forgetting
The secretary calendared the appointments efficiently throughout the day
They calendared the conference sessions by topic and date

definitions: adjust an instrument or device to ensure accurate measurements or readings
mark an instrument with a graduated scale for measurement purposes
examples: The technician calibrated the microscope before the important experiment
You must calibrate the scale weekly for accurate measurements
They calibrated the thermometer with standard reference points carefully
Engineers calibrated the gauge with precision markings yesterday

definitions: measure the dimensions of an object using caliper instruments
examples: The machinist calipered the part to ensure precise specifications
She calipered the thickness of the metal sheet carefully

definitions: speak loudly or shout to attract someone's attention or communicate
contact someone by telephone or other communication device
give a name to someone or describe them in a particular way
summon someone to come or request their presence officially
make a brief visit to a person or place
examples: She called his name across the crowded shopping mall
The mother called her children inside for dinner time
I'll call you tomorrow morning about the meeting details
He called the office to report his absence today
They call him genius because of his brilliant inventions
Don't call me lazy just because I'm resting
The judge called the witness to the stand immediately
The company called all employees for an emergency meeting
The doctor called on his patients every morning routinely
We should call on the new neighbors this weekend

definitions: make or become emotionally hardened and insensitive to others' suffering
form or cause to form hardened thick skin through repeated friction
examples: Years of hardship calloused his heart against compassion
The job calloused her to the suffering of others
Manual labor calloused his hands over many years working
Her feet calloused from years of dancing professionally

definitions: make someone or something become quiet and free from disturbance
become quiet and peaceful after being upset or agitated
examples: She calmed the crying baby with gentle rocking motions
The teacher calmed the excited students before the test
The storm finally calmed after hours of violent winds
He calmed down after taking several deep breaths slowly

definitions: build or shape with a slight upward curve or convex arch
examples: The engineers cambered the road for better water drainage
They cambered the deck to prevent standing water accumulation

definitions: hide or disguise something by making it blend with its surroundings
examples: The soldiers camouflaged their equipment with branches and leaves
The chameleon camouflages itself by changing colors rapidly

definitions: live temporarily in a tent or camp especially for recreation
behave in an exaggerated theatrical or effeminate manner deliberately
examples: We camped by the lake for three nights last summer
The scouts camped in the wilderness learning survival skills
The actor camped it up for the comedy sketch
He camps outrageously at every costume party event

definitions: organize and conduct a series of planned activities for a goal
work actively to promote a political or social cause systematically
examples: She campaigned across the state for six months continuously
The company campaigned aggressively to increase brand awareness nationally
They campaigned for environmental protection through peaceful protests
He campaigned against corruption in local government offices

definitions: preserve food or drink by sealing it in airtight cans
dismiss someone from their job or terminate employment suddenly
examples: They canned tomatoes from their garden every summer harvest
The factory cans thousands of products daily for distribution
The company canned half their workforce during the recession
He got canned for repeatedly arriving late to work

definitions: create or direct water through artificial channels for irrigation or transport
examples: They canalled water from the river to irrigate fields
Engineers canalled the region to improve transportation routes significantly

definitions: decide that a planned event or arrangement will not take place
make something neutral by having an equal and opposite effect
mark something to show it is no longer valid or usable
examples: They cancelled the concert due to severe weather warnings
She cancelled her appointment at the last possible minute
The positive and negative charges cancel each other out
His mistakes cancelled out his earlier good performance
The post office cancelled the stamps with black ink
The bank cancelled the check to prevent fraudulent use

definitions: examine eggs by holding them up to bright light to check quality
examples: The farmer candled the eggs before packaging them for sale
They candled each egg to ensure freshness and quality

definitions: preserve or coat fruit or other food with sugar syrup
cook sugar until it crystallizes or forms a glaze
examples: She candied orange peels for the holiday fruit cake
They candied ginger to use as a sweet garnish
The chef candied the sugar for the dessert decoration
Heat and candy the mixture until it reaches proper consistency

definitions: beat or punish someone using a cane as corporal punishment
weave or repair furniture using strips of cane material
examples: The headmaster caned students for serious disciplinary violations historically
They caned the prisoner as punishment in some countries
She caned the old chair seats using traditional weaving methods
He learned to cane furniture from his grandfather's teachings

definitions: corrupt or cause to decay morally or physically over time
become infected with canker disease or develop ulcerous sores
examples: Jealousy cankered their friendship over many years slowly
Corruption cankered the political system from within gradually
The tree cankered from fungal infection spreading through branches
The wound cankered without proper medical treatment

definitions: collide with something or someone with great force accidentally
fire cannons or heavy artillery in military combat
examples: The car cannoned into the barrier at high speed
The players cannoned into each other during the game
The fortress cannoned the approaching enemy ships relentlessly
They cannoned the walls until they finally collapsed

definitions: travel in or paddle a canoe on water for transport or recreation
examples: They canoed down the river for three days camping
We canoed across the lake to reach the island

definitions: cover or provide shelter with a canopy or overhead covering
examples: Trees canopied the forest path creating natural shade below
They canopied the outdoor market to protect from rain

definitions: tilt or cause to lean at an angle from vertical position
speak in a hypocritical or sanctimonious way about moral issues
examples: The ship canted dangerously in the storm's powerful winds
He canted the barrel to pour out the remaining liquid
Politicians often cant about family values while behaving differently
Stop canting about morality when your actions contradict everything

definitions: ride a horse at a pace between trotting and galloping
examples: She cantered along the beach enjoying the ocean breeze
The horse cantered smoothly around the practice ring

definitions: extend or build a structure projecting horizontally beyond its support
examples: The architect cantilevered the balcony over the cliff edge
They cantilevered the bridge section across the river gap

definitions: put a covering or lid on top of something to close it
set an upper limit on amount or number of something allowed
form a fitting end to something or surpass what came before
examples: She capped the bottle tightly to preserve the contents
Snow capped the mountain peaks throughout the winter months
The government capped spending at ten billion dollars annually
They capped enrollment at five hundred students per year
His final performance capped an amazing career in theater
The touchdown capped their remarkable fourth quarter comeback

definitions: skip or dance about in a lively or playful manner
engage in illegal or questionable activities especially theft
examples: The children capered around the playground during recess time
The lambs capered in the meadow on spring mornings
The gang capered throughout the city stealing valuable artwork
They capered for years before police finally caught them

definitions: write or print text using capital letters at the beginning
use something to your advantage or benefit from an opportunity
provide financial capital or convert assets into capital for business
examples: Remember to capitalise all proper nouns in your essay
She capitalised the first letter of each sentence correctly
The company capitalised on the new market trends successfully
He capitalised on his opponent's mistakes to win
The investors capitalised the startup with ten million dollars
They capitalised their assets to fund the expansion project
